awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Japan
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Justin Havird of Auburn University to conduct a research project in Biological Sciences during the summer of 2013 at The University of the Ryukyus in Okinawa, Japan.  The project title is "Molecular Mechanisms of Salt Balance in Unusual Japanese Shrimps." The host scientists are Drs. Yoshihisa Fujita and Michio Hidaka.

The molecular mechanisms of ionic/salt regulation in crustaceans (i.e., osmoregulation) have only been characterized for a narrow range of species, mainly decapod crabs with a marine ancestry. Atyid shrimps from anchialine habitats (coastal ponds and pools) represent an opportunity to address this lack of knowledge since they have a decisively freshwater ancestry but have adapted to live in these "extreme" environments characterized by drastically fluctuating salinities. Previous research found that the Hawaiian endemic atyid Halocaridina rubra has atypical patterns of gene expression following salinity transfer. Specifically, genes typically and dramatically up-regulated (~100 fold) during salinity transfer in other crustaceans do not change significantly in H. rubra. However, no published studies have examined the molecular mechanisms of osmoregulation or functional evolution of anchialine shrimp species. To examine this in an evolutionary context, the molecular mechanisms of osmoregulation from additional anchialine shrimp species from the Ryukyus Islands, Japan are being investigated using high-throughput measures of gene expression (RNA-Seq). These shrimp species represent independent invasions of anchialine habitats (from both freshwater and marine environments) and characterizing their mechanisms of osmoregulation will thus further our limited understanding of the molecular basis of euryhalinity and address convergent evolution in response to similar natural selection pressures. This project illuminates the evolution of osmoregulation, a critical biological process for all living organisms.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language.   These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.  Furthermore, undergraduates from underrepresented groups in the sciences are being trained and mentored during this project. Additionally, this project is fostering research collaborations between scientists at Auburn University and Oregon State University in conjunction with a recent NSF Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant (DEB 1311500) to the Fellow. The experiences gained from this EAPSI fellowship will be presented to students at Auburn University in an attempt to raise local awareness about international research collaborations in general and the opportunities associated with an EAPSI fellowship specifically. Lastly, anchialine habitats and organisms are being used to engage K-12 students in a variety of biological concepts, building on a current anchialine module in the outreach program Alabama Science in Motion.

Aquatic organisms living in habitats with variable salinities are broadly classified as either osmoconformers (their internal salt concentration mirrors that of the environment) or osmoregulators (they utilize energy to maintain an internal salt concentration differing from the environment). Osmoregulators employ a suite of genes, including ion transporters, exchangers, and channels, to actively excrete or absorb salts depending on environmental conditions. Many of these same genes are expressed in the kidneys of mammals where they participate in maintaining water and salt balance and their malfunctions can lead to human renal diseases. Much of our knowledge regarding the expression of these genes and osmoregulation in general has been garnered from studying crustaceans. However, previous works have examined a limited number of species, focusing mainly on crabs with a marine ancestry. In this context, atyid shrimps from anchialine habitats (coastal ponds and pools) represent an opportunity to further knowledge in this area since they have a decisive freshwater ancestry and have adapted to these “extreme” environments characterized by drastically fluctuating salinities. In support of this, previous research on the Hawaiian endemic atyid Halocaridina rubra identified atypical patterns of gene expression following salinity transfer.

This project examined the evolution of osmoregulatory mechanisms among four anchialine shrimp species via comparative analyses of salinity-induced gene expression patterns. During Summer 2013, individuals of Caridina rubella, Metabetaeus minutus, Antecaridina lauensis, and Halocaridinides trigonophthalma were collected in the Ryukyus (Okinawa) Islands, Japan in collaboration with scientists from the University of the Ryukyus. Each species was chronically acclimated to seawater in the laboratory then transferred to four different salinities typically utilized in osmoregulatory studies of crustaceans. One day following transfer, osmoregulatory (i.e., gills) and control muscle tissues were preserved for gene expression analyses via RNA-Seq, a DNA sequencing-based method that allows simultaneous quantification of all genes being expressed at that timepoint. Other experiments, including post-transfer measurement of hemolymph osmolality and staining/microscopy to determine what gill regions were likely undergoing ion transport in different salinities, were also performed to shed light on osmoregulation in these species. Finally, opportunistic experiments were also performed to examine metabolic rate in response to hypoxia or anoxia for these species.   

Samples (4 species x 2 tissues x 4 salinity transfers x 6 samples per treatment = 192 total) were transported to Auburn University where RNA was extracted from each sample. Currently, cDNA libraries are being prepared and will be sequenced using RNA-Seq as described above. Differentially expressed genes will be identified using established bioinformatics pipelines and statistical analyses. Using this approach, it is hoped that novel osmoregulatory genes/pathways might be identified that are unique to anchialine crustaceans, which would further understanding of osmoregulation in animals (including humans). Moreover, this study may shed light on how anchialine organisms will respond to predicted higher sea surface levels associated with climate change. Finally, evolutionary relationships of the species examined suggest (at least) three independent invasions of anchialine habitats. It will therefore be possible to determine if the alternate osmoregulatory mechanisms observed in H. rubra are characteristic of all anchialine shrimps or only a subset of closely related species.
